context.description: The Breakpoints view lists all the breakpoints you have set.
This command enables the selected breakpoints.
This command disables the selected breakpoints.
This command opens an editor for the file containing the selected breakpoint.
This command selects all breakpoint in the view.
This command deletes the selected breakpoints.
This command deletes all breakpoints in the view.
This command copies the selected breakpoints to the system clipboard.
This command adds breakpoints from the system clipboard to the selected breakpoint group. Breakpoints will only be added if they are valid for the selected group.
This command opens a wizard allowing you to import breakpoints from a file.
When selected, breakpoints will not suspend execution while debugging.
This command opens a wizard allowing you to export your breakpoints to a file.
This command opens a dialog allowing you to choose a working set to be the default working set. New breakpoints will be added to the default working set.
This command opens a dialog allowing you to create, configure and remove working sets.
This command turns off the default working set setting for the breakpoints view.
This command opens a dialog allowing you to edit the working set properties, including its name and what breakpoints it contains.
This command allows you to change whether the selected breakpoint group is the default working set.
When checked, this command configures a watchpoint to suspend execution when a field is accessed (read).
When checked, this command configures a watchpoint to suspend execution when a field is modified (written).
This view shows a collection of available consoles.
This command clears the console.
This command allows you to open a different type of console from the action drop down
This command allows you to pin the current console to always remain on top of other consoles
This command allow you to display a console of your choosing the resutling drop-down menu
This console shows the output of the execution of your program and allows you to enter any necessary user input.

topic.label: Show Console When Standard Out Changes
Show Console When Standard Error Changes

context.description: This command copies the selection to the system clipboard.
Terminates the process associated with the console.
Removes all terminated launches.
Removes the selected launch.
This command enables and disables scroll lock.
This command allows you to select all of the text in the current console.
This command allows you to copy the selected text to the system clipboard and remove it from the current console.
This command allows you to copy text from the system clipboard into the current console.
This command allows you to search for a specified pattern within the current console.
This command opens the preferences page for the console.
This command allows you to search for a specified pattern within the current console.
This command toggles the preference to automatically show the console view when output is written to the standard output stream.

topic.label: Show Console When Standard Out Changes

context.description: This command toggles the preference to automatically show the console view when output is written to the standard error stream.

topic.label: Show Console When Standard Error Changes

context.description: This view displays system processes and the threads and stack frames for each target you are debugging.
This command disconnects the debugger from the selected debug target.

topic.label: Connecting to a remote VM with the Remote Java application launch configuration

context.description: This command opens the launch configuration dialog on the launch configuration associated with the selection.
This command allows you to edit the source lookup path.
Forces source lookup.
This command opens the declared type of the selected stack frame in an editor
This command opens the declared type of the selected stack frame in an editor
This command relaunches the selected debug target or process.
This command resumes the selected thread or the thread containing the selected stack frame.
This command toggles step filters on/off, which are applied to the step into, over, and return commands.
This command steps into the highlighted statement.

This command steps over the highlighted statement. Execution will continue at the next line either in the same method or (if you are at the end of a method) it will continue in the method from which the current method was called.
This command steps out of the current method. The execution stops after exiting the current method.
This command suspends the selected debug target so that you can browse or modify code, inspect data, step, and so on.
This command terminates the selected debug target.

topic.label: Connecting to a remote VM with the Remote Java application launch configuration

context.description: This command terminates all active debug targets.
This command terminates the selected process or debug target and removes it from the view.
This command terminates and removes the selected launch from the debug view
This command opens the view management preference page that is used to control which views are opened and closed while debugging.
This command resets the instruction pointer to the first line of the method associated with the selected stack frame. All frames above the selected stack frame are removed from the stack.
This command removes all terminated launches from the view.

Provides detailed information about the selected variable(s). By default, the detail pane uses a source viewer to display text with source markup. When debugging a Java application, the detail pane displays the toString() value of the selected variable.
This command allows you to assign a new value to the selected variable by evaluating text in the detail pane.
This command opens a popup dialog with context sensitive code help.
This command allows you to copy the selected text to the system clipboard and remove it from the detail pane.
This command copies the selection to the system clipboard.
This command allows you to copy text from the system clipboard into the detail pane.
This command allows you to select all of the text in the detail pane.
This command allows you to search for a specified pattern within the detail pane.
This command toggles word wrap on and off in the detail pane.

topic.label: Wrap Text in the Detail Pane
Max Length in the Detail Pane

context.description: This dialog allows you to change the maximum number of characters allowed in the detail pane.

topic.label: Max Length in the Detail Pane
Wrap Text in the Detail Pane

context.description: This dialog allows you to select variables to be used as launch configuration parameters. Variables are evaluated each time you launch your configuration, which can give your configuration dynamic behavior. Variables specifying 'Selected Resource...' are evaluated to the resource currently selected in the navigator or packages view, etc. at the time the configuration is launched.
This dialog allows you to manage aspects of launching programs from within Eclipse.

topic.label: Creating a Java application launch configuration
Launching a Java program in Debug Mode

context.description: This dialog allows you to edit aspects of the launch configuration for the selected launch.

topic.label: Creating a Java application launch configuration
Launching a Java program in Debug Mode

context.description: Select a type in this tree view to create a new launch configuration. You can also select a specific launch configuration to duplicate, edit or delete it.

Launching a Java program in Debug Mode

context.description: This dialog allows you to edit the current source lookup path.

context.description: This dialog allows you to add one of a variety of source containers to your source lookup path.

context.description: This dialog allows you to edit a launch configuration.

topic.label: Creating a Java application launch configuration
Launching a Java program in Debug Mode

context.description: This wizard page allows you to select breakpoints to export to the local filesystem.
This wizard page allows you to import breakpoints into your workspace from a previously exported file.
This dialog allows you to create a new watch expression.
This dialog allows you to edit an existing watch expression.
This dialog allows you to search for an element by name.
This dialog allows you to select the columns to display in a view.
This dialog allows you to add a memory rendering.
This dialog allows you to create your own custom grouping for your breakpoints in the breakpoints view.
This dialog allows you to add/remove and arrange your favorite launches.

Launching a Java program in Debug Mode

context.description: This dialog allows users to quickly select a new default breakpoint workingset
This dialog prompts users to clean up launch configurations that are associated with, or used to launch code from, the project that is being deleted

context.description: This dialog prompts users to select an available set of modes to set on the current launch configuration in the event the current set is not valid.

context.description: This dialog allows you to select a preferred launcher to continue launching if more than one launcher is available to launch a particular launch configuration in a given mode.

context.description: This dialog is used to select the resources that you wish to save prior to continuing launching. Canceling this dialog will cancel the launch.
This dialog allows you to select a way to launch the currently selected resource.

context.description: This dialog allows you to select a launch configuration.

topic.label: Creating a Java application launch configuration

context.description: This dialog allows you to select a directory from the file system to search for program source.
This dialog allows you to select a type of configuration to create.

context.description: This dialog allows you to select one or more launch configurations to add to your favorites listing.

context.description: This command toggles the breakpoint in the editor ruler.
This view shows the results of inspecting an expression or variable.
This command selects all expressions in the view.
This command deletes the selected expressions.
This command deletes all expressions in the view.
This command adds a watch expression to the Expressions View.
This command reevaluates a watch expression.
This command disables a watch expression.
This command enables a watch expression.
This command allows for editing of watch expressions.
This command replaces the selected object with an equivalent watch expression.
This tab allows you to choose which resources are refreshed when a launch configuration is executed.

Launching a Java program in Debug Mode

context.description: This tab allows you to set the type of the launch configuration, which favorites menu it will be displayed within and whether to launch the configuration in the background.

context.description: This tab allows you to create and configure the environment variables that will be passed into the launch configuration when it is executed

context.description: This tab allows you to specify the launcher to use with the selected launch configuration when more than one is available.

Launching a Java program in Debug Mode

context.description:
The Memory view lets you see blocks of memory rendered into a variety of formats.
The Memory view is divided into two panes. The Monitors pane lists expressions and addresses that have been added to the Memory view. The Renderings pane contains renderings that you add for the memory that is being monitored.
To see memory for a variable or expression in the Memory view, you can use the Add Memory Monitor action and dialog box.
In the view, you can change the contents of memory. You can also change the address range that you want to see in the view.
If you have moved away from the address that you originally set to monitor, choose this action to position the cursor back to the base address of the memory monitor.
Select this to open the Table Renderings Preferences dialog box.

The behavior of this action depends on table renderings preference settings. If you have set table renderings to automatic memory loading mode, selecting the Print action will print the rendering that is currently visible. If you have set table renderings to manual memory loading mode, selecting the Print action will print the entire buffer.
Select this to open the address bar at the bottom of the rendering. The address bar allows you go to an address that you specify, go to an offset, or jump memory units.

The behavior of this action depends on table renderings preference settings. If you have set table renderings to automatic memory loading mode, selecting the Copy To Clipboard action will copy the rendering that is currently visible. If you have set table renderings to manual memory loading mode, selecting the Copy To Clipboard action will copy the entire buffer.
Choose this menu item to remove the selected memory monitor.
Remove all memory monitors from the workbench.
Choose this menu item to remove the selecting rendering.
This action opens a dialog box which allows you to add a memory rendering for any variable or expression that is currently being monitored.
Select this to display the rendering as Little Endian.
Select this to display the rendering as Big Endian.
Select this to display the rendering in its default endianess.
Select this to resize all columns so that all text within them can be viewed.
This action toggles the visibility of the Address column.
This command opens the dialog for setting up codepage preferences in the Memory View.

Use this page to indicate the codepages to use for rendering memory to ASCII and EBCDIC strings.
If you have changed one or both of the values in this page and would like the values to return to default values, click Restore Defaults.
This page sets the codepage for the selected preference.
This commands opens the dialog for setting up the padded string used in memory renderings.

In this page, specify the string that you want to display when memory contents cannot be determined.
If you have changed the padded string value in this page and would like it to return to the default value, click Restore Defaults.
Select this to load the next page of memory.
Select this to load the previous page of memory.
This command displays the renderings associated with the next memory monitor.

If you have moved away from the address that you originally set to monitor, choose this action to position the cursor back to the base address of the memory monitor. By default, the visible renderings will also be reset to the base address. To reset all renderings in the current Memory view to the base address, modify the Memory view preferences.
Select this to open the Format dialog box, which allows you to set the number of units per row and the number of units per column in the memory rendering.
Select this to open the Memory view Preferences dialog box.

The Memory view is divided into two panes. The Monitors pane lists expressions and addresses that have been added to the Memory view. The Renderings pane contains renderings that you add for the memory that is being monitored. You can set these two panes to display in a horizontal orientation (side-by-side) or in a vertical orientation (top-to-bottom) by selecting the appropriate menu item.
This dialog box lets you jump to an address in the memory block.

The address bar allows you to go to a location in memory which you specify. These options are available by pull-down menu in the address bar:
- Go to Address: Select this and then enter an address that you want to jump to. The rendering will be positioned so that the address entered is visible and selected.
- Go to Offset: Select this and then enter the offset. The rendering will be positioned so that the address of the expression (base address), plus the offset entered, is visible and selected. A negative value will position the rendering back from the base address.
- Jump Memory Units: This function takes the currently-selected address and adds the number of memory units that you specify to it. The resulting address is selected. A negative value will position the rendering back from the current address.
For all of these entries, you can input them as HEX by selecting the Input as Hex check box (if this check box is not selected, input will be decimal). Once you have made the entry in the field, hit Enter or click OK to go to the location in the rendering. To close this section, click Cancel.
Preference page for setting the default column size when a new memory monitor is added.
Use this dialog box to specify an address or expression that you would like to add to the Memory view.

Use this dialog box to set the number of units per row and the number of units per column. As you make these settings, the Preview window in the dialog box displays the monitor layout that you are setting. To save these settings as the default layout, click Save as Defaults.
This memory rendering displays content of a memory monitor in table format.
Select this to open the Monitor Memory dialog box, which allows you to specify an address or expression that you would like to add to the Memory view.
Select this to open a page that displays properties for the selected memory.
On this page, you can set preferences for debugging your programs.
On this page, you can set the preferences for the debug console.
On this page, you can configure launch options.
On this page, you can configure the filters used in the launch dialog and migrate launch configurations.
On this page, you can select preferred launch tooling if there are duplicates for any given launch configuration type and set of modes.
On this page, you can configure the perspectives used when running and debugging.
One this page, you can create and configure simple launch variables which you can reference in launch configurations that support variables.
On this page, you can select the perspectives that debug related views will be opened in automatically.

Use this page to configure the memory loading mode in table renderings:
- Automatic: Select this option to have the debugger automatically load a buffer of memory before and after the visible region in the Memory view. When this option is selected, you can easily scroll away from the visible region.
- Manual: Select this option if you want to specify the exact number of lines of memory block to display in the Memory view. When you specify an exact memory block to display, you can only move away from that block by using pop-up menu actions.

You can reset a memory monitor to the base address if you have moved away from it. When you reset a monitor to the base address, you can set it to reset only the visible renderings - or you can set it to reset all renderings. If you choose to reset all renderings, performance of the reset operation can be negatively impacted.
This page displays the run-at time, name and command line used to launch the selected process.
The time when the selected process was initially run.
This page displays properties for the selected memory.
This page displays all of the launch configurations that fall within the scope of the selected resource.
This view displays the registers in your program.
This command re-launches the most recently launched application in debug mode, or debugs the selected resource or active editor, based on your launching preferences
This command allows you to run the selected executable.
This command re-launches the most recently launched application in run mode, or launches the selected resource or active editor, based on your launching preferences
This command allows you to profile the selected executable.
This command re-launches the most recently launched application in profile mode.
This command allows you to inspect the result of evaluating the selected expression.
This command resumes execution to the selected line.
This command opens the launch configuration dialog in debug mode.

topic.label: Creating a Java application launch configuration

context.description: This command opens the launch configuration dialog in run mode.

topic.label: Creating a Java application launch configuration

context.description: This command opens the launch configuration dialog in profile mode.

topic.label: Creating a Java application launch configuration

context.description: This command allows you to select a previous launch from the launch history.
This command opens the launch configuration dialog in the context of the specified launch group.
This command allows you to run the selected executable under debugger control.
This command creates or removes a breakpoint based on the cursor location in the active editor.
This command creates or removes a line breakpoint based on the cursor location in the active editor.
This command creates or removes a method breakpoint based on the cursor location in the active editor or selected method.
This command creates or removes a watchpoint based on the cursor location in the active editor or selected field.
When checked, breakpoints will not suspend execution while debugging.
This command finds an element by name.
This command allows you to change the value of the selected variable.
This command selects all elements in the view.
This command copies a textual representation of the selected variables to the clipboard.
This option can be toggled to show or hide type names of variables in the view.
This command toggles the display of logical variable structure.
Use this menu to choose between several different types of detail panes, each capable of displaying information about selected variables in different ways.
This command reveals the detail pane and sets it in a horizontal alignment within the view.
This command reveals the detail pane and sets it in a vertical alignment within the view.
This command hides the detail pane within the view.
This command toggles whether to display columns in the view.
This command sets the visible columns in the associated view.
This view displays the variables in your program.

topic.label: Show Qualified Names in Variables View
Show Type Names in Variables View
Show Static Fields in Variables View
Change Variable Values in the Variables View

context.description: This command creates a watch expression from the selected variable.
